bibl.title: Letter from Lunsford D. Fricks to Henry Rose Carter, December 9, 1921

div1.p: Fricks seeks Carter's advice on how to publish comprehensive malaria bulletin.

div1.head: Letter from Lunsford D. Fricks to Henry Rose Carter, December 9, 1921
div1.opener:
OFFICE OF
MALARIA INVESTIGATIONS
F.I. - Malaria
Room 17 Court House
JC
TREASURY DEPARTMENT
UNITED STATES
PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE
MEMPHIS. TENN.
December 9, 1921.
N. M C
Fricks
Asst. Surgeon-General H. R. Carter,
U. S. Public Health Service,
2121 California St., N.W.,
Washington, D. C.
Dear Doctor:
div1.p:
While I was in Washington a few days
ago, Dr. Schereschewsky strongly urged the desir-
ability of the Service issuing a publication on
malaria which would be considered an authority on
the subject, similar to the publications previous-
ly issued dealing with milk supply and water pollu-
tion. Dr. Schereschewsky suggested that the dif-
ferent subjects should be handled by those of us
who have been and are now engaged in malaria in-
vestigations and control.

I have talked the matter over with
Mr. LePrince and we are decidedly of the opinion
that the first step should be to secure your ad-
vice in the matter.

It occurs to me that some of the
really valuable bulletins which have already been
published could be incorporated into this enlarged
bulletin, and that perhaps one or two additional
subjects might be included, but I really feel that
we have nothing new except Dr. Barber's Paris green
investigations, and for this reason it might be
better to revise and use the old material.

Will you be good enough to let me know
what you think about the publishing of a comprehensive
malaria bulletin, what it should consist of, and how
we should go about it?
div1.closer:
Very truly yours, L. D. Fricks, Surgeon.
Medical Officer in Charge.
